meanings.def: a grey or white mass that floats in the sky, made of very small drops of water
examples: Dark clouds were gathering in the west.
The cloud cover is quite dense today.
black/grey clouds
thick/dense cloud
The sun went behind a cloud.
It was scorching and there wasn't a cloud in the sky.
in cloud The plane was flying in cloud most of the way.
through the clouds She could see the sun through the clouds.
Rain clouds were looming on the horizon.
The clouds broke a little, and the sun came out.
Thick cloud hung over the moor.
We were flying above the clouds.
White clouds scudded across the sky.
a layer of high cloud
skies of broken cloud
Above the mountains storm clouds were gathering.

meanings.def: a large mass of something in the air, for example dust or smoke, or a number of insects flying all together
examples: a dust cloud
The bees flew out of their hives, forming a thick black cloud.
cloud of something They watched the car disappearing in a cloud of dust.
I saw an enormous cloud of smoke rising over the city.
The sky turned dark as a great cloud of locusts blocked out the sun.
a great cloud of black smoke
a thick cloud of steam
The wind blew across the beach, forming clouds of sand.

meanings.def: something that makes you feel sad or anxious
examples: Her father's illness cast a cloud over her wedding day.
The only dark cloud on the horizon was that they might have to move house.
He still has a cloud of suspicion hanging over him.

meanings.def: a network of servers (= computers that control or supply information to other computers) on which data and software can be stored or managed and to which users have access over the internet
examples: Key company documents are now stored in the cloud, so you no longer need to save them to your computer’s hard drive.

meanings.def: every sad or difficult situation has a positive side
to be thinking about something that is not connected with what you are doing
to have ideas, plans, etc. that are not realistic
if somebody is under a cloud, other people think that they have done something wrong and do not trust them
examples: She left the company under a cloud.

idioms.idiom: every cloud has a silver lining
idioms.def: every sad or difficult situation has a positive side

idioms.idiom: have your head in the clouds
idioms.def: to be thinking about something that is not connected with what you are doing
if somebody is under a cloud, other people think that they have done something wrong and do not trust them
examples: She left the company under a cloud.

meanings.def: if something clouds your judgement, memory, etc., it makes it difficult for you to understand or remember something clearly
examples: Doubts were beginning to cloud my mind.
His judgement was clouded by jealousy.

meanings.def: to show that you feel sad, afraid, angry, etc.; to make somebody look sad, afraid, angry, etc.
examples: cloud (over) Her face clouded over with anger.
cloud something Suspicion clouded his face.

meanings.def: to make something you are discussing or considering less clear, especially by introducing subjects that are not connected with it
examples: Cost factors should not be allowed to cloud the issue.
Further clouding the picture is the question of gender.
It was beginning to cloud over.
That day, the skies had clouded and it had become cool.
The sky clouded over and it started to rain.
His last years were clouded by financial worries.
Her happiness was clouded by having to leave her daughter behind in Jamaica.
His last years were clouded by ill health.

meanings.def: if glass, water, etc. clouds, or if something clouds it, it becomes less easy to see through
examples: cloud (with something) Her eyes clouded with tears.
cloud something Steam had clouded the mirror.
